candidates.title: DON'T set your iPhone to 1 January 1970 or you'll break it
candidates.content:
Apple is warning iPhone users not to fall for an internet hoax that leaves handsets useless and irreparable.
A fake advertisement claims that changing the date on your iPhone to 1 January 1970 will give you a retro Apple design - it doesn't.
And the date change will cause your phone to become permanently stuck while rebooting if it's switched off or runs out of battery.
The bug affects the likes of the iPad Air, Mini 2 and any iPhone 5s onwards.
The prospect of an old skool iPhone attracted many., external
The glitch was discovered last week, but a fake photo has been circulating on social media encouraging people to switch the date on iPhones 5s and upwards.
Users were meant to be able to discover an Easter egg in the form of a 1970s-style multicoloured Apple logo and design.
Unfortunately, going retro on your iPhone won't change the design.
Instead, when the phone is turned off and turned on again, it refuses to reboot, displaying the Apple home screen and going no further.
Get ready for a broken, not a retro phone., external
Incidentally, Apple wasn't even around in 1970. It was founded six years after that.
Any iOS device with a 64 bit processor will be affected.
So the iPhone 5s, 6, 6 Plus, 6s and 6s Plus, the iPad Air 2, the iPad Mini 3 and 4, and the sixth-generation iPod Touch.
candidates.description: Don't believe an internet hoax which claims changing your iPhone date to 1 January 1970 will give you a retro Apple design. It doesn't.

candidates.title: Apple's Blast from the Past?
candidates.content:
Claim:
Setting your Apple device's date to 1 January 1970 will reveal a retro-themed Easter egg.
In February 2016, a rumor began to spread that iPhones and iPads contain a nifty Easter egg: If you set the date of your Apple product to 1 January 1970 then reboot, it will bring up a retro-themed menu based on the old Apple computer operating systems.
Text on the image read:
Blast from the past
The original Macintosh introduced the world to computers, forever changing the way people experience technology, and allowing people to do things that were never possible before. With this easter egg, warp back in time with a class Macintosh theme to relive the magic on your iPhone. Change the date on your iPhone to January 1, 1970, press and hold the power button to reboot your device, and prepare for a wild ride!
As cool as this might look, its a hoax, and a particularly nasty one at that. Resetting your phones date that far back will so thoroughly confuse your phone or tablets operating system that youll either need to take it to the Apple store for a replacement, or just buy a whole new phone or tablet:
If you're worried about doing this by accident, don't. Setting the date on your phone is an onerous and time-consuming process, so theres not much of a chance that you could accidentally brick your phone. However, its possible  at least in theory  that someone with time and malicious intent could trick a phone connected to a network into resetting its date by pretending to be a time server.
The date bug affects iPhones, iPads and iPod touches with 64-bit processors running iOS 8 or iOS 9. Apple says its looking into the bug. According to the Guardian, users can protect themselves with a series of tweaks, such as manually setting their time and date, not enabling automatic time changes, and not turning off their iPhone or iPads.
If you must have an old-school theme for your tablet or phone, fear not: they do exist! (Of course, all caveats about downloading third-party apps and jailbreaking your device do apply.) It's worth noting, by the way, that the very first Apple computer, the Apple I, came out not in 1970, but in 1976.
candidates.description: Setting your iPhone's date to 1 January 1970 won't bring up a cool new theme; it'll just potentially break your device.

result.explanation: Source 1 explicitly states that the claim is an internet hoax and that setting the date to January 1, 1970 will not reveal a retro-themed Easter egg, but instead will break the device. Source 2 also debunks this claim, stating that it is a hoax and will not result in a retro theme, but rather could damage the device.  Both sources contradict the news caption.

final_result.explanation: The internal validation check correctly identifies that the image shows an iPhone with the date set to January 1, 1970, aligning with the caption's claim. However, the external validation check strongly contradicts the caption's claim. Two sources explicitly state that setting the date to January 1, 1970, does not result in a retro-themed Easter egg, but rather can damage the device. This significant disagreement necessitates a careful evaluation. The internal validation's confidence score of 10 reflects a strong alignment between the image and caption, solely based on visual content.  However, the low external validation confidence score of 2, stemming from two independent sources debunking the claim, dramatically diminishes the overall confidence. The external sources provide strong evidence that the claim is a hoax or misinformation. While the image shows the date being set as stated in the caption, the caption's implication of a retro Easter egg is fundamentally incorrect according to reliable external information. Considering the weight of evidence from reputable sources, the caption is out of context, despite the visual consistency.  The visual evidence alone cannot outweigh the clear consensus from external sources indicating the caption's assertion about the Easter egg is false.  There is no visual indication of a retro theme in the image, which further supports the external validation findings.  Therefore, the final assessment concludes that the caption is out of context.

However, external validation from two independent sources conclusively refutes the caption's claim regarding a retro-themed Easter egg, indicating it's a hoax.
